Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Instrumentation for Compound-Specific Stable Isotope Analysis at the University of New Mexico
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non Technical Abstract
The University of New Mexico recently created the Center for Stable Isotopes (UNM-CSI) that is dedicated to enhancing research and training in the application of stable isotope analysis in the biological, geological, anthropological, and medical sciences. Stable isotope analysis (SIA) has revolutionized biology by providing an integrative way to trace elements, the fundamental building blocks of all compounds, from cellular to continental scales. Our project will expand analytical capabilities at UNMCSI to include compound-specific stable isotope analysis (CSIA), an emerging technology that allows for the analysis of individual compounds such as amino acids, fatty acids, and carbohydrates. The acquisition of cutting-edge instrumentation will greatly enhance education and training for students and post-doctoral researchers at UNM. With administrative support, UNM-CSI will offer two research assistantships per semester to train graduate students in the daily operation of instrumentation, QA/QC protocols, and data reduction. In addition, most of the principal investigators associated with this project teach undergraduate and graduate courses that use UNM-CSI as an educational platform; the new instrumentation will expose these students to pioneering technology. Lastly, several of the principal investigators also teach short courses in the U.S. and Latin America on how to apply SIA to research in their respective disciplines, which have attracted >500 graduate students and resulted in a number of students coming to the U.S. to train at UNM-CSI.

Technical Abstract
The majority of SIA applications in biology focus on the analysis of bulk substrates such as plant and animal tissues. CSIA has given biologists a view into the biochemical realm that governs how nutrients are assimilated, synthesized, and transported within and among organisms. The requested instrumentation will greatly enhance opportunities for UNM faculty and students whose research focuses on two general areas: (1) organismal ecology and physiology and (2) paleo-environmental reconstruction. Our research will tackle several CSIA-based projects to (1) examine the role gut microflora play in synthesizing amino acids when their eukaryotic hosts do not consume adequate amounts of protein; (2) explore amino acid hydrogen isotopes in amino acids as novel tracers of food and water use in animals; (3) understand the dynamics of carbon turnover and transport in plants, (4) characterize the consequences of drought and dewatering on population, community, and ecosystem processes in desert aquatic systems, and (5) reconstruct ancient climates via isotope analysis of leaf waxes. Our objectives for having CSIA capabilities at UNM are to pioneer innovative analytical approaches that will be used to address a broad range of questions in biology, and grant the next generation of scientists unimpeded access to cutting-edge technology that has the potential to revolutionize their fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We were awarded funds to expand analytical capabilities in the University of New Mexico’s Center for Stable Isotopes (UNM­-CSI) to include Compound-Specific Stable Isotope Analysis (CSIA). In the past two decades, ecologists and ecological-physiologists have adopted stable isotope analysis (SIA) as a tool to quantify the flow of energy within and among ecosystems, characterize animal migration strategies, and examine nutrient allocation in plants and animals. The large majority of studies utilizing SIA focus on analysis of bulk substrates (e.g., plant and animal tissues); however, CSIA involves innovative analysis of the individual compounds (e.g., amino or fatty acids) from which tissues are constructed provides unique information on the underlying biochemical processes that control observed isotopic patterns within and among organisms.

UNM-CSI is a new interdisciplinary research and training center that supports research groups across campus as well as groups from other institutions. The requested instrumentation has greatly enhanced, and continues to enhance, opportunities for UNM faculty and students whose research focuses on two general areas: (1) organismal ecology and physiology and (2) paleo-environmental reconstruction. Our objectives for having CSIA capabilities at UNM are to pioneer innovative analytical approaches that will be used to address a broad range of questions in biology and earth sciences, and grant the next generation of scientists unimpeded access to cutting-edge technology that has the potential to revolutionize their fields.

Our equipment was purchased during winter 2015 and installed in spring 2015. Since then the instruments have operated nearly continuously and have produced data for a wide variety of projects. We have supported research for seven faculty and graduate students from four departments within the College of Arts and Sciences and the School of Engineering at the University of New Mexico, and twenty-one faculty from other institutions. In addition, we have hosted graduate students from other institutions that are using the instrumentation to produce data for their theses. We have experienced no major issues with the equipment beyond routine maintenance.

Results of ongoing work utilizing the purchased instrumentation were or will be presented at multiple national meetings in 2015–2017, including annual meetings of the Ecological Society of America, American Physiological Society, Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology, Society for Marine Mammalogy, American Quaternary Association, Society for American Archaeology, IsoEcology, Alaska Marine Science Symposium, Channel Islands Symposium, and the Latin American Society of Specialists in Aquatic Mammals (SOLAMAC).

In accordance with the educational mission of the UNM-CSI, the instrumentation is being used by graduate students, undergraduate students, and postdoctoral scientists. Specifically, three post-doctoral fellows have benefitted from the instrumentation by producing isotope data for amino and fatty acids that is integral to a wide variety of projects in ecology, ecological-physiology, and engineering. In addition, seven graduate students have been trained to operate and maintain the instrumentation to analyze carbon and nitrogen isotopes of individual amino acids, and four graduate students from other institutions have visited UNM-CSI to run samples as part of collaborative projects between PI Newsome and their primary advisors at their home universities. At least six undergraduate students have used the UNM-CSI for senior honors thesis.

Graduate student education and training is being enhanced at UNM–CSI through an apprenticeship program in which two students per semester are being trained in the daily operation of instrumentation, instrument maintenance, QA/QC protocols, and data reduction; these students are funded via two graduate research assistantships available through the Biology and Earth & Planetary Sciences Departments. We have also developed a scholarship competition in which students submit 1–2 page proposals to analyze ~50–100 samples that would provide pilot data for larger proposals.

In addition to providing a platform for faculty and graduate student research, the requested instrumentation is playing an important role in classroom and laboratory education at UNM. For example, Biology Department faculty and co-PIs Hanson and Wolf currently teach upper-level undergraduate and graduate courses that use the instrumentation at UNM­–CSI as an educational platform. PI Newsome offers an upper-level undergraduate and graduate course in Elemental Ecology that is taught every other year that includes a laboratory component where students learn sample preparation protocols and complete a project with field- and/or museum-collected plant and animal tissues. Lastly, the requested instrumentation is available as a teaching resource for undergraduate and graduate students taking other courses in sub-disciplines that commonly use SIA, including animal/plant physiology, mammalogy, ichthyology, ornithology, and herpetology.
